meanings.definition: To adjust or mark (a measuring instrument) so that it can be used in an accurate and precise way.
meanings.sent1: I need to calibrate the thermometer to make sure it shows the correct temperature.
meanings.sent2: The technician will calibrate the scale before weighing the ingredients.
meanings.sent3: Trying to calibrate a broken ruler is like trying to fix a crooked mirror.
meanings.sent4: Her keen eye for detail allowed her to calibrate her camera perfectly for the photoshoot.
meanings.sent5: The scientist had to calibrate the telescope to capture the faintest stars in the night sky.

meanings.definition: To make small changes to something in order to improve its performance or accuracy.
meanings.sent1: We should calibrate the settings on the machine for better results.
meanings.sent2: The mechanic will calibrate the engine to ensure it runs smoothly.
meanings.sent3: He tried to calibrate his dance moves, but ended up looking like a robot.
meanings.sent4: She needed to calibrate her speech to connect with the young audience.
meanings.sent5: The coach had to calibrate the team's strategy to adapt to the opponent's tactics.
